factoid: Prince Andrew mentioned what he had written to an old field marshal.
The old field marshal was a friend of Prince Andrew's father's.
The field marshal made an appointment to see Prince Andrew.
The field marshal received Prince Andrew graciously.
The field marshal promised to inform the Emperor.
Prince Andrew received notice that he was to go to see the Minister of War, Count Arakchéev.
Prince Andrew was to go to see Count Arakchéev.
Count Arakchéev is the Minister of War.
Prince Andrew entered Count Arakchéev's waiting room at nine in the morning.
Prince Andrew did not know Count Arakchéev personally.
Prince Andrew had never seen Count Arakchéev.
Prince Andrew had heard of Count Arakchéev.
Prince Andrew's hearing of Count Arakchéev inspired him with little respect for Count Arakchéev.
Prince Andrew thought that Count Arakchéev is trusted by the Emperor.
Prince Andrew thought that Count Arakchéev has been commissioned to consider Prince Andrew's project.
Prince Andrew thought that Count Arakchéev alone can get the project adopted.
Prince Andrew was waiting among a number of important and unimportant people in Count Arakchéev's waiting room.
Prince Andrew had served chiefly as an adjutant.
Prince Andrew had seen the anterooms of many important men.
Prince Andrew was well acquainted with different types of such rooms.
Count Arakchéev’s anteroom had a special character.
The faces of unimportant people awaiting their turn for an audience showed embarrassment and servility.
The faces of higher rank people awaiting their turn expressed a common feeling of awkwardness.
The faces of higher rank people were covered by a mask of unconcern.
The faces of higher rank people were covered by a mask of ridicule of themselves, their situation, and the person they were waiting for.
Some people walked thoughtfully up and down.
Some people whispered.
Some people laughed.
Prince Andrew heard the nickname Síla Andréevich in reference to Count Arakchéev.
Prince Andrew heard the words "Uncle will give it to us hot" in reference to Count Arakchéev.
One general was an important personage.
The general was evidently feeling offended at having to wait so long.
The general sat crossing and uncrossing his legs.
The general smiled contemptuously to himself.
When the door opened, fear appeared on all faces.
Prince Andrew asked the adjutant on duty to take his name for the second time.
The adjutant on duty gave Prince Andrew an ironical look.
The adjutant on duty told Prince Andrew that his turn would come in due course.
Some others had been shown in and out of the minister's room by the adjutant on duty.
An officer was admitted at that door.
The officer struck Prince Andrew by his humiliated and frightened air.
The officer's audience lasted a long time.
A harsh voice was heard from the other side of the door.
The officer had a pale face and trembling lips.
The officer came out and passed through the waiting room clutching his head.
Prince Andrew was conducted to the door.
The officer on duty whispered "To the right, at the window."
Prince Andrew entered a plain tidy room.
Prince Andrew saw at the table a man of forty with a long waist, a long closely cropped head, deep wrinkles, scowling brows above dull greenish-hazel eyes, and an overhanging red nose.
Count Arakchéev turned his head toward Prince Andrew without looking at him.
Count Arakchéev asked Prince Andrew, "What is your petition?"
Prince Andrew returned that he is not petitioning, addressing Count Arakchéev as your excellency.
Count Arakchéev's eyes turned toward Prince Andrew.
Count Arakchéev said "Sit down."
Count Arakchéev addressed Prince Andrew as Prince Bolkónski.
Prince Andrew said he is not petitioning about anything.
Prince Andrew said His Majesty the Emperor has deigned to send Count Arakchéev a project submitted by him.
Count Arakchéev said, "You see, my dear sir, I have read your project."
Count Arakchéev uttered the words amiably.
Count Arakchéev then relapsed into a tone of grumbling contempt.
Count Arakchéev asked Prince Andrew if he was proposing new military laws.
Count Arakchéev said there are many laws but no one to carry out the old ones.
Count Arakchéev said nowadays everybody designs laws, it is easier writing than doing.
Prince Andrew said he came at His Majesty the Emperor's wish to learn from Count Arakchéev how he proposes to deal with the memorandum presented.
Prince Andrew said he came politely.
Count Arakchéev said he has endorsed a resolution on Prince Andrew's memorandum and sent it to the committee.
Count Arakchéev said he does not approve of the resolution.
Count Arakchéev rose and took a paper from his writing table.
Count Arakchéev said "Here!" and handed the paper to Prince Andrew.
Across the paper was scrawled in pencil: "Unsoundly constructed because resembles an imitation of the French military code and from the Articles of War needlessly deviating."
Prince Andrew inquired what committee the memorandum had been referred to.
Count Arakchéev replied that the memorandum had been referred to the Committee on Army Regulations.
Count Arakchéev said he recommended Prince Andrew should be appointed a member of the Committee on Army Regulations, but without a salary.
Prince Andrew smiled.
